Authorization to proceed with project prior to obtaining written approvals? |CC
As per our meeting on Wednesday, April 13th with Carl Cohen and Mark Walchak, and our :selected: 'Ye's :unselected:
subsequent telephone conversations with Mark on April 14th, we have been requested to continue with designs for the Brand X project as follows:
- As a result of preliminary research testing of selected designs for this project, we are to prepare the following additional design revisions.
- Basically the consumers did not like the white background shown on the test designs as they were viewed as being generic, especially in combination with a red, white and blue color scheme.
- The designs showing the kraft background was viewed as being more like a cigar product, too strong, heavy looking.
- The use of a script for the logo was also viewed as being somewhat confusing, that "Phil" (Mel, Jake, or Dave) wouldn't necessarily write or sign their names this way, etc., that a simple typeface or printed name would be more appropriate.
- Also the use of gold on the design, especially if a lot of gold is used was not in keeping with Phil's. - The all red background pack design wasn't appropriate for Phil's, it was too much, too heavy, etc.
Based upon the above information, Carl would like for us to take our original Phil's design P3-12550 (P4-12550) and prepare additional face panel Iris color prints with the following revisions.
. Take the Phil's symbol and lighten the overall color scheme to make It less reminiscent of a cigar product.
- Perhaps the design itself can be modified so that it is less of a cigar band by taking the Phil's ribbon and changing it to more of a diagonal ribbon. Try this in combination with a lighter color scheme.

printed name would be more appropriate.
- Also the use of gold on the design, especially if a lot of gold is used was not in keeping with Phil's.

Based upon the above information, Carl would like for us to take our original Phil's design P3-12550

. Take the Phil's symbol and lighten the overall color scheme to make It less reminiscent of a cigar
- Perhaps the design itself can be modified so that it is less of a cigar band by taking the Phil's
ribbon and changing it to more of a diagonal ribbon. Try this in combination with a lighter color

As per our meeting on Wednesday, April 13th with Carl Cohen and Mark Walchak, and our :selected: 'Ye's :unselected:
subsequent telephone conversations with Mark on April 14th, we have been requested to continue with designs for the Brand X project as follows:
- As a result of preliminary research testing of selected designs for this project, we are to prepare the following additional design revisions.
- Basically the consumers did not like the white background shown on the test designs as they were viewed as being generic, especially in combination with a red, white and blue color scheme.
- The designs showing the kraft background was viewed as being more like a cigar product, too strong, heavy looking.

- The use of a script for the logo was also viewed as being somewhat confusing, that "Phil" (Mel, Jake, or Dave) wouldn't necessarily write or sign their names this way, etc., that a simple typeface or printed name would be more appropriate.

- Also the use of gold on the design, especially if a lot of gold is used was not in keeping with Phil's. - The all red background pack design wasn't appropriate for Phil's, it was too much, too heavy, etc.
Based upon the above information, Carl would like for us to take our original Phil's design P3-12550 (P4-12550) and prepare additional face panel Iris color prints with the following revisions.
. Take the Phil's symbol and lighten the overall color scheme to make It less reminiscent of a cigar product.

- Perhaps the design itself can be modified so that it is less of a cigar band by taking the Phil's ribbon and changing it to more of a diagonal ribbon. Try this in combination with a lighter color scheme.
